text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
HET FINANCIEELE DAGBLAD
- Dutch banks fight for more flexible labour market legislation enabling them to hike the share of performance-related pay. (p1)
- Retail group Vendex International to boost its market share in Dutch grocery sector. (p1)
- Government gives go-ahead for four "Top Technology Institutes" (TTIs), but not for a research institute to study embedded systems. (p1)
- Printer and copier maker Oce says recent acquisitions boost Q1 net by more than half. (p3)
- Sanitaryware manufacturer Sphinx Gustavsberg sells off its bathroom fittings subsidiary Schock Bad. (p3)
- China calls off Dutch trade mission led by economic affairs minister Hans Wijers after Dutch criticise Peking's human rights policy. (p3)
- Financial services group ING group launches options plan for its staff as part of employee loyalty programme. (p4)
- Supermarkets giant Ahold takes over institutional groceries supplier Van der Spek from Campina Melkunie. (p5)
DE VOLKSKRANT
- FNV trade union federation flooded with membership cancellations after draft agreement with employers on demotion of older employees. (p1)
- Philips Electronics drags down combined 1996 profit growth of AEX-listed companies to four percent. Excluding Philips it would have been nearly 15 percent. (p2)
- Vendex International aims to raise 600 million guilders from bourse launch of its temp employment unit Vedior. (p2)
- Chemicals company DSM reports leakages of benzene amounted to 400 rather than 170 tonnes. (p6)
DE TELEGRAAF
- Employers' asssociation VNO-NCW chief Hans Blankert hits out at Dutch foreign affairs minister Hans van Mierlo, saying he has lost Dutch industry billions of guilders in rowing with China. (p1)
- Steel concern Hoogovens OVENC.AS to issue 300-350 million guilders' worth of subordinated convertibles bonds for 300-350 million guilders. (p19)
- ING Investment management bolsers its asset management position in Czech Republic and Hungary. (p21)
- Computer chips industry supplier ASM Lithography doubles its production capacity with immediate effect. (p21) TROUW
- Traffic ministry investigates possiblity of a parallel runway to one of Schiphol airport's existing runways. (p1)
- U.S. biotech firm Centocor invests in its Leiden-based unit for first time in four years. (p2)
ALGEMEEN DAGBLAD
- Environment minister Margreet de Boer proposes offsetting increased carbon dioxide emissions from Amsterdam's Schiphol airport by stepping up green investments in eastern Europe. (p4)
